FedBC: Calibrating Global and Local Models via
Federated Learning Beyond Consensus

Amrit Singh Bedi â€ƒâ€ƒ Chen Fan â€ƒâ€ƒ Alec Koppel â€ƒâ€ƒ Anit Kumar Sahu â€ƒâ€ƒ Brian M. Sadler â€ƒâ€ƒ Furong Huang â€ƒâ€ƒ Dinesh Manocha
Abstract

In this work, we quantitatively calibrate the performance of global and local models in federated learning through a multi-criterion optimization-based framework, which we cast as a constrained program. The objective of a device is its local objective, which it seeks to minimize while satisfying nonlinear constraints that quantify the proximity between the local and the global model. By considering the Lagrangian relaxation of this problem, we develop a novel primal-dual method called Federated Learning Beyond Consensus (FedBC). Theoretically, we establish that FedBC converges to a first-order stationary point at rates that matches the state of the art, up to an additional error term that depends on a tolerance parameter introduced to scalarize the multi-criterion formulation. Finally, we demonstrate that FedBC balances the global and local model test accuracy metrics across a suite of datasets (Synthetic, MNIST, CIFAR-10, Shakespeare), achieving competitive performance with state-of-the-art.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) has gained popularity as a powerful framework to train machine learning models on edge devices without transmitting the local private data to a central server (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Mathematically, we can write the FL problem as

minğ±âˆˆğ’³â¡Fâ€‹(ğ±):=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ±),assignsubscriptğ±ğ’³ğ¹ğ±1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\displaystyle\min_{{{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{X}}}F({\mathbf{x}}):=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}), (1)

where ğ’³âŠ‚â„dğ’³superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{X}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} is a compact convex set and Fâ€‹(ğ±)ğ¹ğ±F({\mathbf{x}}) is the sum of Nğ‘N possibly non-convex local objectives fiâ€‹(ğ±)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}) which could be stochastic as well fiâ€‹(ğ±):=ğ”¼Î¶iâ€‹[fâ€‹(x,Î¶i)]assignsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±subscriptğ”¼subscriptğœğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘“ğ‘¥subscriptğœğ‘–f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}):=\mathbb{E}_{\zeta_{i}}[f(x,\zeta_{i})] with Î¶iâˆ¼â„™â€‹(Î¶i)similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘–â„™subscriptğœğ‘–\zeta_{i}\sim\mathbb{P}(\zeta_{i}). Following standard FL literature (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020)), we consider that all the devices are connected in a star topology to a central server. The FL problem is challenging because of the heterogeneity across devices which might be due to different sources, such as the local training data sets can have different sample sizes and might not even necessarily be drawn from a common distribution, meaning that â„™â€‹(Î¶i)â„™subscriptğœğ‘–\mathbb{P}(\zeta_{i}) is allowed to be heterogeneous for each device iğ‘–i. The goal of standard FL is to train a global model ğ±âˆ—superscriptğ±{\mathbf{x}}^{*} by solving (1), which performs well or at least uniformly across all the clients (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020).

In the presence of data heterogeneity across devices, it is highly unlikely that one global model would work well for all devices. This has been highlighted in (Li etÂ al., 2019), where a large spread in terms of performance of the global model was noted across devices. The requirement of uniform performance of the global model across devices is also connected to fairness in FL (Li etÂ al., 2019). In FL, the global model is generally constructed from an aggregation of local models learned at each device. The simplest is the average of local models in FedAVG (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). When devicesâ€™ local objectives are distinct, solving (1) can potentially lead to global model which is far away from the local model obtained by solving:

minğ±âˆˆğ’³â¡fiâ€‹(ğ±),subscriptğ±ğ’³subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\displaystyle\min_{{{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{X}}}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}), (2)

for device iğ‘–i. For instance, consider the problem of learning â€œlanguage modelsâ€ for a cellphone keyboard, where the goal is to predict the next word. FL can be used in such a case to learn a common global model, but a global model might fail to capture distinctive writing styles, as well as the cultural nuances of different users. In such a case, a specific local model [cf. (2)] for each device is required; however, due to sub-sampling error, data at device iğ‘–i might not be sufficient to obtain a reasonable model via only local data. Therefore, there are two competing criteria: global performance in terms of (1) evaluated at the global model and a local performance evaluated at the local model [cf. (2)]. The notion of global and local models naturally arises in FL and exists in FedAVG (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020), SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), etc. Predominately, the focus in the existing literature is either on training only the global model or the local model. Hence we pose the following question:

â€œHow can one automate the balance between global and local model performance simultaneously in FL?â€

We answer this question affirmatively in this work by developing a novel framework of federated learning beyond consensus (FedBC). We note that balancing between the global model in (1) and local model (2) in general involves multi-objective optimization (Tan etÂ al., 2022). This class of problems cannot be solved exactly, especially in the case of non-convex local objectives with heterogeneous data, and may be approximately solved with the scalarized composite criterion Î±â€‹fiâ€‹(ğ±)+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹(1/N)â€‹âˆ‘ifiâ€‹(ğ±)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±1ğ›¼1ğ‘subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\alpha f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})+(1-\alpha)(1/N)\sum_{i}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}) (Jahn, 1985).

In this work, we reinterpret augmentation (which may be interpreted as an extension of the proximal augmentation approaches in (Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2020; TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020)) as (i) a constrained optimization alternative to scalarizing the multi-criterion problem of finding a minimizer simultaneously of (1) and (2), and (ii) a relaxation to forcing consensus among local models and making them same for all the devices which is the standard practice in FL. We propose to consider a problem in which the global objective (1) is primal, which owing to node-separability, allows each device to only prioritize its local objective (2). Then, we introduce a constraint to control the deviation of the local model from the global model with a local hyper-parameter Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} for each device iğ‘–i.

Contributions. We summarize our main contributions as follows:

(1) We propose a novel framework of federated learning beyond consensus, which allows us to calibrate the performance of global and local models across devices in FL as a multi-criterion problem to be approximated through a constrained non-convex program (cf. 7). This formulation itself is novel for the FL settings.

(2) We derive the Lagrangian relaxation of this problem and an instantiation of the primal-dual method, which, owing to node-separability of the Lagrangian, admits a federated algorithm we call FedBC (cf. Algo. 1).

(3) We establish the convergence of the proposed FedBC theoretically and show that the rates are at par with the state of the art. We also illustrate the efficacy of FedBC via showing the performance of global and local models on a range of datasets (Synthetic, MNIST, CIFAR-10, Shakespeare).

Related Works. Current approaches in literature tend to focus either only on the performance of the global model (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), or the local model (Fallah etÂ al., 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020), but do not quantitatively calibrate the trade-off between them. Prioritizing global model performance only amongst the individual devices admits a reformulation as a consensus optimization problem (Nedic & Ozdaglar, 2009; Nedic etÂ al., 2010), which gives rise to FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). In this context, it is well-known that averaging steps approximately enforce consensus (Shi etÂ al., 2015), whereas one can enforce the constraint exactly by employing Lagrangian relaxations, namely, ADMM (Boyd etÂ al., 2011), saddle point methods (NediÄ‡ & Ozdaglar, 2009), and dual decomposition (Terelius etÂ al., 2011). This fact has given rise to efforts to improve the constraint violation of FL algorithms, as in FedPD (Zhang etÂ al., 2021) and FedADMM (Wang etÂ al., 2022). Other approaches involve using model-agnostic meta-learning (Fallah etÂ al., 2020), in which one executes one gradient step as an approximation for (2) as input for solving (1) with objective 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ±âˆ’Î±â€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±))1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±ğ›¼âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}-\alpha\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})). However, it does not explicitly allow one to trade off local and global performance. Several works have sought to balance these competing local and global criteria based upon regularization (Li etÂ al., 2020; Hanzely etÂ al., 2020; TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020; Li etÂ al., 2021b). Alternatives prioritize the performance of the global model amidst heterogeneity via control variate corrections (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Acar etÂ al., 2021). Please refer to Appendix A for additional related work context.

2 Problem Formulation

In this section, to solve (1) in a federated manner, we consider a consensus reformulation of (1), where each device iğ‘–i is now only responsible for its local copy ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–{\mathbf{x}}_{i} of the global model ğ³ğ³{\mathbf{z}}:

min{(ğ³,ğ±i)âˆˆğ’³}â€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ±i)s.t.Â â€‹ğ±i=ğ³,âˆ€i.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ’³superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–s.t.Â subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³for-allğ‘–\displaystyle\min_{\{{({\mathbf{z}},{\mathbf{x}}_{i})\in\mathcal{X}}\}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{s.t. }{\mathbf{x}}_{i}={\mathbf{z}},\ \ \forall i. (3)

The linear equality constraints ğ±i=ğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³{\mathbf{x}}_{i}={\mathbf{z}} for all iğ‘–i in (3) enforce consensus among all the devices. To solve (3), one may employ techniques from multi-agent optimization (Nedic & Ozdaglar, 2009; Nedic etÂ al., 2010) and consider localized gradient updates followed by averaging steps, as in FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). Setting aside the issue of how sharply one enforces the constraints for the moment, observe that in (3), each device must balance between the two competing global and local objectives. These quantities only coincide when the set of minimizers of the sum is contained inside the set of minimizers of each cost function in the sum. This holds only when the sampling distributions â„™â€‹(Î¶i)â„™subscriptğœğ‘–\mathbb{P}(\zeta_{i}) coincide which is not true for FL in general. Efforts to deal with the gap between the global (1) and local (2) objectives have relied upon augmentations of the local objective, e.g.,

fiâ€‹(ğ±i)+(Î¼/2)â€‹â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ³â€–2subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğœ‡2superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³2\displaystyle f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i})+(\mu/2)\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}-{\mathbf{z}}\|^{2} in FedProx,in FedProx\displaystyle\text{in FedProx}, (4)
argâ¡minğœ½â¡fiâ€‹(ğœ½)+(Î¼/2)â€‹â€–ğœ½âˆ’ğ³â€–2subscriptğœ½subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ½ğœ‡2superscriptnormğœ½ğ³2\displaystyle\arg\min_{\bm{\theta}}f_{i}(\bm{\theta})+(\mu/2)\|\bm{\theta}-{\mathbf{z}}\|^{2} in pFedMe,in pFedMe\displaystyle\text{in pFedMe}, (5)
fiâ€‹(ğ±âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±))subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\displaystyle f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}-\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})) in Per-FedAvg.in Per-FedAvg\displaystyle\text{in Per-FedAvg}. (6)

In the above objectives, observe that a penalty coefficient is introduced to obtain a suitable tradeoff between global and local performance. This relationship is even more opaque in meta-learning, as the tradeoff then depends upon mixed first-order partial derivatives of the local objective with respect to the global model â€“ see (Fallah etÂ al., 2020). Therefore, it makes sense to discern whether it is possible to obtain a methodology to solve for the suitable trade-off between local and global performance while solving for the model parameters themselves. To do so, we reinterpret the penalization in (4) as a constraint, which gives rise to the following problem:

min{(ğ³,ğ±i)âˆˆğ’³}â€‹âˆ‘i=1Nfiâ€‹(ğ±i)s.t.Â â€‹â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ³â€–2â‰¤Î³i,âˆ€i,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ’³superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–s.t.Â superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–for-allğ‘–\displaystyle\min_{\{{({\mathbf{z}},{\mathbf{x}}_{i})\in\mathcal{X}}\}}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{s.t. }\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}-{\mathbf{z}}\|^{2}\leq\gamma_{i},\ \ \forall i\;, (7)

for some Î³iâ‰¥0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}\geq 0. We call this formulation FL beyond consensus because Î³i>0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}>0 would allow local models to be different from each other and no longer enforces consensus as in (3).

Interpretation of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}: The introduction of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} provides another degree of freedom to the selection of local ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–{\mathbf{x}}_{i} and global model ğ³ğ³{\mathbf{z}}. Instead of forcing ğ±i=ğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³{\mathbf{x}}_{i}={\mathbf{z}} for all iğ‘–i in (3), they both can differ from each other while still solving the FL problem. For instance, consider the example in Fig. 1 (left), where we generalize the example from (Tan etÂ al., 2022) and show (Fig. 1 (right)) that a strictly positive Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} can result in a better global model. Further, as a teaser in Fig. 2, we also note experimentally that Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} calibrates the trade-off between the performance of the local and global model. For simplicity in Fig. 2, we kept Î³ğ›¾\gamma the same for all iğ‘–i, and we note that local test accuracy and global test accuracy both increase as we start increasing Î³ğ›¾\gamma from zero, and then eventually global performance starts deteriorating after Î³>0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma>0.05 and local performance is still improving. This makes sense because by making Î³ğ›¾\gamma larger, we are just focusing on minimizing the individual loss functions for each device iğ‘–i than focusing on minimizing the sum.

But remarkably, the region between 0â‰¤Î³â‰¤0.050ğ›¾0.050\leq\gamma\leq 0.05 is interesting because both local and global performance increases, which tells us that Î³=0.05ğ›¾0.05\gamma=0.05 is superior to choosing than Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 as used in the standard FL (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020). Hence, this basic experiment in Fig. 2 establishes that there is some room to improve the existing FL models (even if we just focus on the performance of the global model) with a non-zero Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}, which has not yet been utilized anywhere to the best of our knowledge, and may be interpreted as the scalarizing coefficient in the aforementioned multi-criterion objective in Sec. 1. Therefore, this work is the first attempt to show the benefits of using Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0. We further solidify our claims in Sec. 5. Next, we derive an algorithmic tool to solve (7).

3 FedBC: Federated Learning Beyond Consensus

To solve (7), one could consider the primal-dual method (NediÄ‡ & Ozdaglar, 2009) or ADMM (Boyd etÂ al., 2011). However, as the constraints [cf (7) are nonlinear, ADMM requires a nonlinear optimization in the inner loop. Thus, we consider the primal-dual method, which may be derived by Lagrangian relaxation of (7) as:

where â„’iâ€‹(ğ³,ğ±i,Î»i):=[fiâ€‹(ğ±i)+Î»iâ€‹(â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ³â€–2âˆ’Î³i)]assignsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\mathcal{L}_{i}({\mathbf{z}},{\mathbf{x}}_{i},\lambda_{i}):=\big{[}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i})+\lambda_{i}\left(\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}-{\mathbf{z}}\|^{2}-\gamma_{i}\right)\big{]}. Connection to Existing Approaches: FL algorithms alternate between localized updates and server-level information aggregation. 4 Convergence Analysis

In this section, we establish performance guarantees of Algorithm 1 in terms of solving the global [cf. (1)] and the local problem (2). We first state the assumptions:

Assumption 4.1.

The domain ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} of functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} in (2) is compact with diameter Rğ‘…R, and at least one stationary point of âˆ‡ğ±iâ„’iâ€‹(ğ±i,ğ³,Î»i)=0subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptâ„’ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³subscriptğœ†ğ‘–0\nabla_{{\mathbf{x}}_{i}}\mathcal{L}_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i},{\mathbf{z}},\lambda_{i})=0 belongs to ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}.

Assumption 4.2 (Lipschitz gradients).

The gradient of the local objective âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}) of each device is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ²)â€–â‰¤Liâ€‹â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ²â€–normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ²subscriptğ¿ğ‘–normğ±ğ²\|\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})-\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{y}})\|\leq L_{i}\|{\mathbf{x}}-{\mathbf{y}}\|, âˆ€ğ±,ğ²âˆˆğ’³for-allğ±ğ²ğ’³\forall{\mathbf{x}},{\mathbf{y}}\in\mathcal{X}\;.

Assumption 4.3 (Bounded Heterogeneity).

For any device pair (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j), it holds that max(a,b)âˆˆÎ›â¡â€–aâ€‹âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)âˆ’bâ€‹âˆ‡fjâ€‹(ğ±)â€–â‰¤Î´subscriptğ‘ğ‘Î›normğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±ğ‘âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ±ğ›¿\max_{(a,b)\in\Lambda}\|a\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}})-b\nabla f_{j}({\mathbf{x}})\|\leq\delta, for all ğ±âˆˆğ’³ğ±ğ’³{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathcal{X}.

Next, we describe the assumption required when we use stochastic gradients instead of the actual gradients. If we denote the stochastic gradient for agent iğ‘–i as ğ isubscriptğ ğ‘–{\mathbf{g}}_{i}, it satisfies the following assumption.

Assumption 4.4 (Stochastic Gradient Oracle).

If a stochastic gradient oracle is used at device iğ‘–i, then ğ isubscriptğ ğ‘–{\mathbf{g}}_{i} satisfies ğ”¼â€‹[ğ i|â„‹k]=âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±i)ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ ğ‘–subscriptâ„‹ğ‘˜âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbb{E}[{\mathbf{g}}_{i}\leavevmode\nobreak\ |\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathcal{H}_{k}]=\nabla f({\mathbf{x}}_{i}), Â Â and Â Â  ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ iâˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±i)â€–2|â„‹k]â‰¤Ïƒ2ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ ğ‘–âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘–2subscriptâ„‹ğ‘˜superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}[\|{\mathbf{g}}_{i}-\nabla f({\mathbf{x}}_{i})\|^{2}\leavevmode\nobreak\ |\leavevmode\nobreak\ \mathcal{H}_{k}]\leq\sigma^{2}, Â Â âˆ€ifor-allğ‘–\forall{i}, where â„‹ksubscriptâ„‹ğ‘˜\mathcal{H}_{k} is defined as filtration or Ïƒğœ\sigma-algebra generated by past realizations {Î¶iu}u<ksubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘¢ğ‘¢ğ‘˜\{\zeta_{i}^{u}\}_{u<k}.

We note that the Assumptions 4.1-4.4 are standard (Nemirovski etÂ al., 2009). Assumption 4.2 makes sure that the local non-convex objective is smooth with parameter Lisubscriptğ¿ğ‘–L_{i}. Assumption 4.3 is a version of the heterogeneity assumption considered in the literature (Assumption 3 in (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020)). Assumption 4.4 imposes conditions on the stochastic gradient oracle, particularly unbiasedness and finite variance, which are standard. We are now ready to present the main results of this work in the form of Theorem 4.5. For the convergence analysis, we consider the performance metric 1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=1Tâ€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ³t)â€–21ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ³ğ‘¡2\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\|\nabla f({\mathbf{z}}^{t})\|^{2} which is widely used in the literature (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020). Under these conditions, we have the following convergence result.

Theorem 4.5.

Under Assumption 4.1-4.3, for the iterates of proposed Algorithm 1, we establish that the global performance satisfies:

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ³t)â€–2]=1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptğ³ğ‘¡2absent\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f({\mathbf{z}}^{t})\|^{2}]= ğ’ªâ€‹(B0T)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµ)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î´2)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î±)ğ’ªsubscriptğµ0ğ‘‡ğ’ªitalic-Ïµğ’ªsuperscriptğ›¿2ğ’ªğ›¼\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{B_{0}}{T}\right)+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon)+\mathcal{O}(\delta^{2})+\mathcal{O}(\alpha)
+ğ’ªâ€‹(1Nâ€‹Tâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NÎ³i),ğ’ª1ğ‘ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\displaystyle+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{NT}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\gamma_{i}\right), (14)

where B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is the initialization dependent constant, Ïµ=maxiâ¡Ïµiitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ‘–subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon=\max_{i}\epsilon_{i} is the accuracy with each agent solves the local optimization problem in the algorithm, Î´ğ›¿\delta is the heterogeneity parameter (cf. Assumption 4.3), Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0 is the step size, and Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}â€™s are the local parameters.

The proof of Theorem 4.5 is provided in Appendix C. The expectation in (4.5) is with respect to the randomness in the stochastic gradients and device sampling. The first term is the initialization dependent term, and as long as the initialization B0subscriptğµ0B_{0} is bounded, the first term reduces linearly with respect to Tğ‘‡T and goes to zero in the limit as Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty. This term is present in any state-of-the-art FL algorithm (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020). The second term is ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ’ªitalic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(\epsilon), which depends upon the worst local approximated solution across all the devices. Note that the individual approximation errors Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} depend on the number of local iterations Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i}. This term is also present in most of the analyses of FL algorithms for non-convex objectives. The third term is due to the heterogeneity across the devices and is a specific feature of the FL problem. The fourth term is the step size-dependent term. The last term is important here because that appears due to the introduction of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} in the problem formulation in (7), and it is completely novel to the analysis in this work. This term decays linearly even if Î³i>0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}>0 for all iğ‘–i. The Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}â€™s are directly affecting the global performance because they are allowing device models to move away from each other, hence affecting the global performance. We remark that for the special case of Î³i=0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}=0 for all iğ‘–i, our result in (4.5) is equivalent to FedPD (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), pFedMe (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020) except for the fact that there is no device sampling in FedPD.

The technical points of departure in the analysis of FedBC (cf. Algorithm 1) from prior work are associated with the fact that we build out from an ADMM-style analysis. (Zhang etÂ al., 2021) However, due to non-linear constraint (7), one cannot solve the argminargmin\operatornamewithlimits{argmin} exactly. This introduces an additional ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ’ªitalic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(\epsilon) error term that we relate to Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i} in (10). This issue also demands we constrain the dual variables to a compact set in (11). Moreover, device sampling for the server update (cf. (13)) is introduced here for the first time in a primal-dual framework, which does not appear in (Zhang etÂ al., 2021). Furthermore, our nonlinear proximity constraints [cf. (7)] additionally permits us to relate the performance in terms of the local objective [cf. (2)] to the proximity to the global model defined in (7) as a function of tolerance parameter Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}. We formalize their interconnection in the following corollary.

Corollary 4.6 (Local Performance).

Under Assumption 4.1-4.3, for the iterates of Algorithm 1, we establish that

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=1Tâ€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±it)â€–2â‰¤1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡2absent\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\|\nabla f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{t})\|^{2}\leq ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµi)ğ’ªsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\displaystyle\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon_{i}\right)
+Î±2â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹([âˆ‘k=0Tğ•€{âˆ¥ğ±ikâˆ’ğ³kâˆ’1âˆ¥2â‰¤Î³i)}]+)2.\displaystyle+\alpha^{2}\mathcal{O}\left(\bigg{[}\sum_{k=0}^{T}\mathbb{I}_{\{\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{k}-{\mathbf{z}}^{k-1}\|^{2}\leq\gamma_{i})\}}\bigg{]}_{+}\right)^{2}. (15)

The proof is provided in Appendix D. We note that the local stationarity of each client iğ‘–i actually depends on the local Ïµisubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–\epsilon_{i} approx error and Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} via a complicated term present in the second term in (15), where ğ•€ğ•€\mathbb{I} is an indicator function that is 111 if the condition is not satisfied, and âˆ’11-1 otherwise. We note that the term inside the big bracket is larger (worse local performance) for lower Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}, and vice versa. Hence we have a relationship between global and local model performance in terms of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}.

5 Experiments

In this section, we aim to address the following questions with our experiments: â‘  Does the introduction of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} help FedBC to improve global performance compared to other FL algorithms in heterogeneous environments? â‘¡ Does FedBC allow users to have their own localized models and to what extent? Interestingly, we observed that FedBC, with the help of Î³i>0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–0\gamma_{i}>0, tends to weight the importance of each device equally and hence achieves fairness as defined by Li etÂ al. (2019). We specifically test the fairness of the global model in terms of its performance on user/derive with minimum data (called min user) and device with maximum data (called max user) in the experiments. Please refer to Appendix E for additional detailed experiments.

Experiment Setup. The synthetic dataset is associated with a 101010-class classification task, and is adapted from (Li etÂ al., 2020) with parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta controlling model and data variations across users (see Appendix E.1 for details). For real datasets, we use MNIST and CIFAR-101010 for image classification. MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets consist of handwritten digits and color images from 101010 different classes respectively (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) (LeCun etÂ al., 1998). We denote Cğ¶C to represent the most common number of classes in usersâ€™ local data (see Appendix E.3 for details). To evaluate the global performance of FedBC, we compare it with 444 other FL algorithms, i.e., FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), q-FedAvg (Li etÂ al., 2019), FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020), and Scaffold (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020). We use the term global accuracy while reporting the performance of the global model (ğ³tsuperscriptğ³ğ‘¡{\mathbf{z}}^{t}) on the entire test dataset and use the term local accuracy while reporting the performance of each deviceâ€™s local model (ğ±itsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{t}) using its own test data and take the average across all devices.

Selection of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}: Since we do not know the optimal Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} for each user iğ‘–i apriori, for experiments, we initialize them to be 00, and propose a heuristic to let the device decide its own Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}. To achieve that, we observe Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} participating in the Lagrangian defined in (8) and which defines a loss with respect to primal variables, and we want to minimize it. Hence, we take the derivative of the Lagrangian in (8) with respect to Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}, and perform a gradient-descent update for Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}. Interestingly, we note that the derivative of Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} is âˆ’Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–-\lambda_{i}, which means that Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} tends to always increase when gradient descent is performed. This implies that initially, each deviceâ€™s local model remains closer to the global model (similar to standard FL), but gradually incentivizes moving away from the global model to improve the overall performance. Experimentally, we show that this heuristic works very well in practice. (see Appendix E.1 for additional details).

Synthetic Dataset Experiments: We start by presenting the global accuracy results of the synthetic dataset classification task in Table 1. Note that FedBC outperforms all other algorithms for different numbers of local training epochs Eğ¸E. Figure 3 provides empirical justifications for such remarkable performance. Figure 3(a) shows that FedBC achieves a lower training loss than others, whereas algorithms such as FedAvg plateaus at an early stage. Next, to understand the calibrating behavior of FedBC, we compare the contributions from min and max usersâ€™ local models (defined in Figure 3 caption) in updating the global model ğ³tsuperscriptğ³ğ‘¡{\mathbf{z}}^{t} via (13). To this end, we plot their Î»isubscriptğœ†ğ‘–\lambda_{i}s at the end of each communication round in Figure 3(b). It is evident that FedBC is significantly less biased towards the min user. The min userâ€™s coefficient eventually catches that of the max user for FedBC, and the difference between them is one order of magnitude less than that of the data-size-based coefficient. This enables FedBC to be better in terms of fairness as compared to other algorithms. Figure 3(c) shows the distribution of Î»ğœ†\lambda- coefficients at the end of training for devices of different data sizes. Interestingly, the max userâ€™s coefficient is almost the same as those of users of small data sizes. In fact, the coefficients of users of data size less than 300300300 for FedBC are consistently larger than their data-size-based counterparts, and vice versa for data sizes greater than 300300300. Lastly, Figure 3(d) shows the model of FedBC achieves a high uniformity in test accuracy over usersâ€™ local data at different values of Eğ¸E.

To further emphasize the fairness aspect of FedBC, we plot the test accuracy of the global model on min and max usersâ€™ local data throughout the entire communication in Figure 4. We observe that the global model performs better on max userâ€™s data than on min userâ€™s data in general for all algorithms. Most importantly, FedBC demonstrates a superior advantage in reducing this performance gap. After 100100100 rounds of communication, test accuracy for min and max users are nearly the same, as shown in Figure 4(a). Whereas for FedAvg (Figure 4(b)), this gap can be as large as 100%percent100100\% even after nearly 200200200 rounds of communication. As compared to q-Fedavg (Figure 4(c)), FedProx (Figure 4(d)), or Scaffold (Figure 4(e)), FedBC has a much higher fraction of points at which test accuracy for min and max user overlap, which indicates that they are being treated equally well (enforcing fairness). We also present additional results in Appendix F (Figure 10-12) for E=25,50ğ¸2550E=25,50, because the local model differs more from the global model as Eğ¸E increases. The trend is similar, and FedBC can still make good predictions on the min userâ€™s local data despite an increase in the performance gap compared to E=5ğ¸5E=5. This is significantly different from the case of FedAvg, in which its model fails to make any correct predictions on the min userâ€™s local data for the majority of times, as shown in Figure 10-12 in Appendix F. In essence, FedBC has the best performance because it allows users to participate fairly in updating the global model. This performance benefit is credited to using non-zero Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}, which is the main contribution of this work.

Real Dataset Experiments: The experiments on real datasets are in line with our previous observations in Figure 3. We first report the results for global model performance on the CIFAR-10 dataset in Table 2 for E=5ğ¸5E=5 (see Appendix 6 for E=1ğ¸1E=1). We note that FedBC outperforms FedAvg by 7.89%percent7.897.89\% for C=3ğ¶3C=3. For the most challenging situation of C=1ğ¶1C=1, FedBC outperforms all other baselines. The superior performance of FedBC is attributed to the fact that we observe unbiasedness in computing the coefficient for the global model when C=1ğ¶1C=1, 222, or 333 (see Figure 13 in Appendix G.1). We also observe the high uniformity in test accuracy over usersâ€™ local data for all classes with different power law exponents (see Figure 15 in Appendix G.1).

We show the classification results on MNIST in Table 7 and Table 8 in Appendix G.2 and observe that FedBC outperforms all the other baselines. We also present the results on the Shakespeare dataset in Table 9 in Appendix G.3. From Table 2, we also notice the global performance of pFedMe and Per-FedAvg is worse than that of FedAvg, FedProx or FedBC when C=1ğ¶1C=1. This is mainly because personalized algorithms are designed to optimize the local objective of (2). However, this may create conflicts with the global objective in (1) and lead to poor global performance.

Local Performance. We have established that a non-zero Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} in FedBC leads to obtaining a better global model. This is because it provides additional freedom to automatically decide the contributions of local models rather than sticking to a uniform averaging, as done in existing FL methods. But a remark regarding the individual performance of local models ğ±itsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{t} is due. We can evaluate the test accuracy of local model ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–{\mathbf{x}}_{i} at each device iğ‘–i to see how it performs with respect to local test data. Table 3 presents the local performance of FedBC and other personalization algorithms. We observe that FedBC performs better and worse than pFedMe and Per-FedAvg, respectively. We can expect this performance because our algorithm is not designed to just focus on improving the local performance compared to pFedMe and Per-FedAvg. But an interesting point is that we can utilize the local models ğ±itsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{t} obtained by FeBC to act as a good initializer, and after doing some fine tuning at device iğ‘–i, can improve the local performance as well. For instance, by doing 111-step fine-tuning on the test data (we call it FedBC-FineTune), we can improve the local performance of FedBC. For example, FedBC-FineTune achieves a 7.55%percent7.557.55\% performance increase over FedBC when C=3ğ¶3C=3. To further improve the local model performance, as an additional experimental study, we incorporated MAML-type training into FedBC (cf. Algorithm 3 in Appendix E.4), which we call Per-FedBC algorithm, we can significantly improve the local performance for both C=1ğ¶1C=1 and C=3ğ¶3C=3.

Takeaways: In summary, we experimentally show that FedBC has the best global performance when compared against all baselines (addresses â‘ ). Moreover, FedBC has reasonably good local performance but can be improved by fine-tuning or performing MAML-type training (addresses â‘¡). We leave the question of how to fully exploit the advantage in the freedom of choosing Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} to achieve personalization for future work.

6 Conclusions

In this work, we delved into the intricate relationship between local and global model performance in federated learning (FL). We introduced a new proximity constraint to the FL framework, enabling the automatic determination of local model contributions to the global model. Our research demonstrates that by recognizing the flexibility to not force consensus among local models, we can simultaneously improve both the global and local performance of FL algorithms. Building on this insight, we developed the novel FedBC algorithm, which has been shown to perform well across a broad range of synthetic and real data sets. It outperforms state-of-the-art methods by automatically calibrating local and global models efficiently across devices.

Appendix A Additional Context for Related Work

In the existing literature, the problem of improving the performance of the global model on all the devices (global performance) (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Li etÂ al., 2020; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020; Acar etÂ al., 2021) and local devices (personalization) are considered in a separate manner (Fallah etÂ al., 2020). Hence, we categorize the related literature into two parts as follows.

FL for Global Model Performance: One of the first popular algorithms to solve the federated learning is FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). The idea of FedAvg is to learn a common model for all the devices while updating local models at each device only without communicating local data with the central server. This suffers from the well-known client-drift problem and is further improved in FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020), SCAFFOLD (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), FedDyn and (Acar etÂ al., 2021). Recently, a primal-dual-based approach was proposed called FedPD (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), which also achieves state-of-the-art performance in terms of convergence rate. These works focus on ensuring consensus among the models learned for each device. In this work, we depart from this concept and introduce a novel formulation of federated learning beyond consensus.

FL for Local Model Performance: To improve local model performance/personalization, there are mainly two strategies which are employed to introduce personalization into the FL problem, namely: global model personalization via meta-learning based methods (Fallah etÂ al., 2020) and learning personalized models directly (Tan etÂ al., 2022). In global model personalization, the idea is to learn a common global model in such a way that it performs well when used for the localized objectives after some tuning (Fallah etÂ al., 2020) [some other papers]. Meta-learning is the core idea that is utilized to achieve that. In the second strategy, the focus is on learning specific personalized models for each device to obtain better local performance (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020). The problem with existing personalized methods is that they ignore global performance completely and just focus on local performance. In contrast, in this work, we are trying to find a balance between the two.

Lemma B.2.

Under Assumption 4.1-4.3, for the iterates of proposed Algorithm 1, we establish that the consensus error satisfies:

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=0Tâˆ’1[1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ±it+1âˆ’ğ³t+1â€–2]]â‰¤1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡0ğ‘‡1delimited-[]1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘¡1superscriptğ³ğ‘¡12absent\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\mathbb{E}\big{[}\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{t+1}-{\mathbf{z}}^{t+1}\|^{2}\big{]}\right]\leq ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïµ)+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î´2),ğ’ªitalic-Ïµğ’ªsuperscriptğ›¿2\displaystyle{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}\mathcal{O}\left({\epsilon}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left({\delta^{2}}\right)}, (44)

=\displaystyle= â€–1âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’®tÎ»jt+1â€‹âˆ‘jâˆˆğ’®tÎ»jt+1â€‹(ğ±it+1âˆ’ğ±jt+1)â€–2,superscriptnorm1subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘—ğ‘¡1subscriptsuperscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘—ğ‘¡12\displaystyle\Bigg{\|}\frac{1}{\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\lambda_{j}^{t+1}}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\lambda_{j}^{t+1}({\mathbf{x}}^{t+1}_{i}-{\mathbf{x}}_{j}^{t+1})\Bigg{\|}^{2}, (45)

Appendix D Proof of Corollary 4.6

Proof.

Here we prove the effect of the introduced parameter Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i} on the local/personalized performance of the proposed algorithm. Appendix E Additional Details of the Experiments

E.1 Experiment Setup

Datasets. We perform experiments on both synthetic and real datasets. The devices are heterogeneous due to non-independent and identically distributed (non-iid) data. The degree of correlation is manifested through the heterogeneous class distribution across devices and the variability in the size of the local dataset at each device.

  • â€¢

    The synthetic dataset is for a 101010-class classification task, and is adapted from (Li etÂ al., 2020) with parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta controlling model and data variations across devices. Specifically, each deviceâ€™s local model is a multinomial logistic regression of the form yi=argmax(softmaxâ€‹(ğ–ğ¢â€‹ğ±ğ¢+ğ›ğ¢))subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–argmaxsoftmaxsubscriptğ–ğ¢subscriptğ±ğ¢subscriptğ›ğ¢y_{i}=\operatornamewithlimits{argmax}(\text{softmax}(\mathbf{W_{i}x_{i}}+\mathbf{b_{i}})) with ğ–ğ¢âˆˆâ„10Ã—60subscriptğ–ğ¢superscriptâ„1060\mathbf{W_{i}}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 60} and ğ›ğ¢âˆˆâ„10subscriptğ›ğ¢superscriptâ„10\mathbf{b_{i}}\in\mathbb{R}^{10} as in (Li etÂ al., 2020). The local data (ğ±ğ¢,yi)subscriptğ±ğ¢subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–(\mathbf{x_{i}},y_{i}) of each device is generated according to (Li etÂ al., 2020). We sample ğ–ğ¢âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ui,1)similar-tosubscriptğ–ğ¢ğ’©subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1\mathbf{W_{i}}\sim\mathcal{N}(u_{i},1) and ğ›ğ¢âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ui,1)similar-tosubscriptğ›ğ¢ğ’©subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–1\mathbf{b_{i}}\sim\mathcal{N}(u_{i},1) where uiâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î±)similar-tosubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ’©0ğ›¼u_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha). We sample ğ±ğ¢subscriptğ±ğ¢\mathbf{x_{i}} from ğ’©â€‹(ğ¯ğ¢,ğšº)ğ’©subscriptğ¯ğ¢ğšº\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v_{i}},\mathbf{\Sigma}), where ğšºğšº\mathbf{\Sigma} is a diagonal matrix with entries ğšºj,j=jâˆ’1.2subscriptğšºğ‘—ğ‘—superscriptğ‘—1.2\mathbf{\Sigma}_{j,j}=j^{-1.2}, and each entry of ğ¯ğ¢subscriptğ¯ğ¢\mathbf{v_{i}} is from ğ’©â€‹(Bk,1)ğ’©subscriptğµğ‘˜1\mathcal{N}(B_{k},1), Bkâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Î²)similar-tosubscriptğµğ‘˜ğ’©0ğ›½B_{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\beta). We set Î±=Î²=0.5ğ›¼ğ›½0.5\alpha=\beta=0.5, and partition the data among 303030 devices according to a power law.

  • â€¢

    For real datasets, we use MNIST and CIFAR-101010 for image classification and the Shakespeare dataset for the next character prediction task. MNIST (LeCun etÂ al., 1998) and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) datasets consist of handwritten digits and color images from 101010 different classes. We follow the strategy from (Stripelis & Ambite, 2020) to distribute the data to 202020 devices following a power law with a preset exponent (Data size range and distribution for each exponent are shown in Table 5 and Figure 5). To preserve the power law relationship, we allow some devices to have more classes than others, as in (Stripelis & Ambite, 2020). Table 4 summarizes the number of classes each device has for different power law exponents. We denote Cğ¶C to represent the most common number of classes owned by devices. For example, CIFAR-10 with C=2ğ¶2C=2 and exponent 1.21.21.2 is distributed as {1Ã—5,2Ã—4,17Ã—2}1524172\{1\times 5,2\times 4,17\times 2\}, which means 111 device has 555 classes, 222 devices have 444 classes, and the rest 171717 devices have 222 classes. Besides computer vision tasks, we also perform experiments on natural language processing tasks such as next-character prediction on the Shakespeare dataset from (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). The dataset is composed of character sequences from different speaking roles. We assign each speaking role to a device, and we subsample 138138138 device.

Architectures. For the MNIST dataset, we use a neural network consisting of 222 fully-connected layers with 128128128 hidden dimensions. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, we use a 222-layer convolutional neural network with 555 as kernel size. The first and second layers have 666 and 161616 filters, respectively (Li etÂ al., 2021a). After each convolution operation, we apply 2Ã—2222\times 2 max pooling and Relu activation. For the Shakespeare dataset, we use a 2-layer LSTM with 256256256 as the dimension of the hidden state. The input to this model is a character sequence of length 808080, and we embed it into a vector of size 888 before passing it into the LSTM (Li etÂ al., 2019).

Baselines. We use the term global accuracy when evaluating the performance of the global model using the entire test dataset. We use the term local accuracy when evaluating the performance of each deviceâ€™s local model using its own test data and take the average across all devices. To evaluate the global accuracy of FedBC in terms of the prediction accuracy of test data across all the devices, we compare it with 666 other federated learning algorithms, i.e., FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), q-FedAvg (Li etÂ al., 2019), FedProx (Li etÂ al., 2020), Scaffold (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020), Per-FedAvg (Fallah etÂ al., 2020) and pFedMe (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020). For Per-FedAvg and pFedMe, we us the model at the server to evaluate the global performance across all the devices. Besides the baseline algorithms mentioned above, we compare the performance of local models of FedBC with personalization algorithms such as Per-FedAvg (Fallah etÂ al., 2020) and pFedMe (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020). To further enhance the performance of local models, we fine-tune the local models of FedBC by performing 111-step gradient descent using a batch of test data and name this approach as FedBC-FineTune. In the end, as an experimental study, we also incorporate MAML-type training into FedBC, and propose algorithm Per-FedBC (see appendix E.4). Similar to FedBC-FineTune, we also perform the 111-step fine-tuning step using test data for Per-FedBC or Per-FedAvg following (Fallah etÂ al., 2020).

For FedAvg and Scaffold, we search the learning rate (lâ€‹rğ‘™ğ‘Ÿlr) in the range [0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1.0]0.0010.010.10.51.0[0.001,0.01,0.1,0.5,1.0]. For q-FedAvg, we tune qğ‘q in the range [0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0,2.0,5.0]0.0010.010.11.02.05.0[0.001,0.01,0.1,1.0,2.0,5.0] (see (Li etÂ al., 2019) for the definition qğ‘q). For FedBC, we tune the learning rate for the Lagrangian multiplier Î»ğœ†\lambda (lâ€‹rÎ»ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğœ†lr_{\lambda}) when updating it through gradient ascent in the range [10âˆ’7,10âˆ’6,10âˆ’5,0.0001,0.001,0.01]superscript107superscript106superscript1050.00010.0010.01[10^{-7},10^{-6},10^{-5},0.0001,0.001,0.01]. As mentioned in E.1, we also perform a gradient-descent type update for the constant Î³isubscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\gamma_{i}. We set its learning rate equal to lâ€‹rÎ»ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿğœ†lr_{\lambda} to limit the search cost, and it works well in practice. For Per-FedAvg, we choose the inner-level learning rate (Î±ğ›¼\alpha) and outer-level learning rate (Î²ğ›½\beta) to be 0.010.010.01 and 0.0010.0010.001 as in (Fallah etÂ al., 2020). For Per-FedBC (see Algorithm 3), we set Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta to be the same as Per-FedAvg with J=1ğ½1J=1. We subsample 101010 devices at each round of communication for all algorithms and perform 555 local training epochs unless otherwise stated (we enote the number of local training epochs as Eğ¸E). Once the optimal hyperparameter is found, we perform 555 parallel runs to compute the standard deviation for each algorithm. We use an 80%/20%percent80percent2080\%/20\% train/test split for all datasets.

E.3 Data Partitioning

Table 4 summarizes the class partitioning for MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. In this table, Cğ¶C represents the most common number of classes owned by devices. Devices in the head of the power law data size distribution are given more classes than others as in (Stripelis & Ambite, 2020). For example, C=1ğ¶1C=1 with power law exponent 1.11.11.1 for MNIST has the class partitioning {2Ã—3,5Ã—2,13Ã—1}2352131\{2\times 3,5\times 2,13\times 1\}, which means 222 devices have 333 classes, 555 devices have 222 classes, and 131313 devices have 111 classes. Table 5 summarizes the range of data sizes for different power law exponents. For example, for CIFAR-10 with a power law exponent 1.11.11.1, the number of data a device has is between 104710471047 and 643364336433. Figure 5 and Figure 6 further show the number of data each device has for real and synthetic datasets, respectively.

E.4 Per-FedBC Algorithm

The idea of MAML is to find a good global initializer that can be quickly adapted to new tasks (Fallah etÂ al., 2020), i.e., solve the objective of (6). Its derivative involves second-order terms, which creates computational burden. A first-order approximation, i.e. FO-MAML, ignores them to avoid this problem. More generally, a MAML problem can be viewed as a bilevel optmization problem in which the upper-level objective is to find and update this initializer, and the lower-level objective is to fine-tune the initializer based on specific task information (Fan etÂ al., 2021). We utilize this idea to propose an advanced version of FedBC called Per-FedBC for experimental purposes.

Due to the constraint in (6), we treat the inner objective of the form â„’iâ€‹(ğ³,ğ±i,Î»i):=[fiâ€‹(ğ±i)+Î»iâ€‹(â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ³â€–2âˆ’Î³i)]assignsubscriptâ„’ğ‘–ğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğœ†ğ‘–superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ³2subscriptğ›¾ğ‘–\mathcal{L}_{i}({\mathbf{z}},{\mathbf{x}}_{i},\lambda_{i}):=\big{[}f_{i}({\mathbf{x}}_{i})+\lambda_{i}\left(\|{\mathbf{x}}_{i}-{\mathbf{z}}\|^{2}-\gamma_{i}\right)\big{]}. Hence, when we update each deviceâ€™s local model based on this objective, it has a term associated with the global model ğ³tsuperscriptğ³ğ‘¡\mathbf{z}^{t}. We also ignore any second-order derivatives to reduce computation cost, hence different from Per-FedAvg. First, the local updates involve Lagrange multipliers due to constraint penalization. Second, we also perform the dual updates as in FedBC. Third, we follow the aggregation strategy based on Lagrange multipliers as in FedBC to update the global model. We summarize the steps in Algorithm 3 and report the performance of Per-FedBC in Table 3.

Appendix F Additional Experiments on Synthetic Dataset

F.1 Training loss for different Epochs Eğ¸E and Lagrangian visualization

Figure 7 shows the training loss for different Eğ¸Es. We observe that FedBC achieves the lowest train loss for E=1,10,25ğ¸11025E=1,10,25 and 505050 compared to other algorithms. These observations are consistent with Figure 3(a). We also observe some divergence in the training loss of the Scaffold for high E=25ğ¸25E=25 and 505050. Figure 8 shows the coefficient of min and max user/device when computing the global model for E=1,10,25ğ¸11025E=1,10,25 and 505050. We observe that the coefficient based on the Lagrangian multiplier is consistently less biased towards the min user than its data-size-based counterpart for all Eğ¸Es, which provides additional evidence besides Figure 3(b) to show that the devices of FedBC participate fairly in updating the global model. This improves the fairness of the global model obtained by FedBC.

Lagrangian visualization. Since we are introducing Lagrangian variables via FedBC, we further track the Lagrangian multipliers (Î»ğœ†\lambda) at different rounds of communication and plot their magnitudes for all devices in 7(e). We observe that devices of small data sizes can have Î»ğœ†\lambdas that are very similar in magnitudes to devices of large data sizes at different rounds of communication. This shows that the fair aggregation of local models for FedBC occurs throughout the training process and not only in the end as shown in Figure 3(c). The results in Table 1 is based on 303030 total number of devices. Here, we provide additional results for the different total numbers of devices as shown in Figure 7(f). We observe that FedBC outperforms other algorithms when the total number of devices is 303030 or 707070. FedBC and Scaffold have similar performance and outperform others when this becomes 100100100.

F.1.1 Evidence of Fairness Induced by FedBC

Figure 3 and Figure 8 together show the global model of FedBC incorporates feedback from local models in an unbiased way. In Figure 8, we plot the coefficient which decides the contribution of min and max user towards the global model and plots it against the number of communication rounds. We plot it for different values of Eğ¸E. We note from Figure 8 that the contribution coefficients are (red and green) becoming similar as the communication rounds increase, ensuring the unbiased nature of the FedBC algorithm. Because of this, it can perform well on both the min and max deviceâ€™s local data, as shown in Figure 4. We can see the difference between the final values of data size-based contribution coefficients (orange and blue), which are quite different, resulting in biased behavior.

Test accuracy of min and max user/device. To further solidify our claim, we plot the test accuracy of min and max user/device in Figure 9-12 for E=1,10,25ğ¸11025E=1,10,25 and 505050, respectively. We observe that FedBC is the best in eliminating the difference in test accuracy of min and max userâ€™s local data for all Eğ¸Es. We also notice this difference is most apparent when E=50ğ¸50E=50 for all algorithms as shown in Figure 12. As Eğ¸E increases, each deviceâ€™s local model would differ more from the global model. This creates challenges for the global model to perform well on all deviceâ€™s local data. When we compare Figure 12(a) and Figure 12(b), we see the striking difference between FedBC and FedAvg. For FedAvg, the global model performs poorly on the majority of min users as their test accuracy is 0%percent00\%. For FedBC, there is no performance gap for most points. This shows that the global model of FedBC is able to perform well on the deviceâ€™s local data despite the presence of high dissimilarity between local and global models.

G.1 Experiments on CIFAR-10 Dataset

For example, for E=1ğ¸1E=1 and C=3ğ¶3C=3 in Figure 14(c), FedBC has the smallest variance of test accuracy for all power law exponents. In the main body of the paper, Table 2 (for E=5ğ¸5E=5) and Table 3 shows the global and local performance of FedBC respectively for all Cğ¶Cs and power law exponents 1.1,1.2,1.3,1.41.11.21.31.41.1,1.2,1.3,1.4, and 1.51.51.5. In Table 2, we first observe that FedBC has the best global performance for all exponents in the most challenging case when C=1ğ¶1C=1. For power law exponent is 1.1, Per-FedAvg has the best local performance. We also observe significant performance improvements of FedBC-FineTune over FedBC. For example, when the power law exponent is 1.31.31.3, FedBC-FineTune outperforms FedBC by 16.99%percent16.9916.99\% in test accuracy for C=3ğ¶3C=3. In general, FedBC has the best global accuracy among all algorithms. Its personalization performance can be largely improved when combined with Fine-Tuning or MAML-type training as in Algorithm 3.

G.2 Experiments on MNIST Dataset

We present the global performance results for the MNIST classification task in Table 7 and Table 8 for E=1ğ¸1E=1 and E=5ğ¸5E=5, respectively. The results are consistent with those of CIFAR-10. We again observe that FedBC has good performance for different Cğ¶Cs and power law exponents. For example, when C=1ğ¶1C=1 and 1.31.31.3 as power law exponent, FedBC outperforms FedAvg by 3%percent33\% for both E=1ğ¸1E=1 and E=5ğ¸5E=5. We also observe that FedBC outperforms others when exponents are 1.21.21.2, 1.41.41.4, and 1.51.51.5 for C=1,3ğ¶13C=1,3 with E=5ğ¸5E=5. These results demonstrate that FedBC achieves the best global performance for different datasets under challenging heterogeneous environments.

G.3 Experiments on Shakespeare Dataset

For the Shakespeare dataset, we report the global model performance for the next-character prediction task in Table 9. The top row presents the mean prediction accuracy. We observe algorithms have very similar performance when E=1ğ¸1E=1 or 555 except for Scaffold. For E=1ğ¸1E=1, FedBC outperforms q-FedAvg and Scaffold, but performs slightly worse than FedAvg and FedProx. For E=5ğ¸5E=5, FedBC has the best performance. The second row presents the variance of test accuracy over deviceâ€™s local dataset. We observe Scaffold has the smallest variance. The variance of FedBC is larger than Scaffold but smaller than others when E=1ğ¸1E=1; it is smaller than FedAvg but greater than others when E=5ğ¸5E=5. In general, the performance of FedBC on the Shakespeare dataset is competitive when compared against others.
